top_categories.workout_context: At 100 miles, The Mid South punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Racing The Mid South isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
The Mid South’s rolling red clay gravel and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
The Mid South’s oklahoma red clay roads, rolling hills demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Every session at The Mid South intensity builds on this aerobic foundation — the endurance base is the soil everything else grows in.
The Mid South rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
At 100 miles, The Mid South rewards a massive aerobic engine. This volume work builds the fat-oxidation capacity that keeps you moving when glycogen runs low.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at The Mid South — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on rolling red clay gravel.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at The Mid South — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of The Mid South. Make this intensity feel like home.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at The Mid South when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what The Mid South’s rolling red clay gravel delivers on race day.

race_overlay.heat: March in Stillwater, Oklahoma — Early March brings 40-75°F swings, potential freezing rain, potential heat, potential wildfires. Begin heat acclimatization 10–14 days before The Mid South — 20–30min sauna sessions or midday rides in full kit. Pre-load sodium 48 hours out. Target 500–750ml/hr with electrolytes on race day.
race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for The Mid South’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at The Mid South requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on rolling red clay gravel to build confidence. Expect: oklahoma red clay roads, rolling hills, exposed ridgelines.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Durability, Race Simulation, and VO2max to prepare you for 100 miles of rolling red clay gravel in Stillwater, Oklahoma.
